bat thesis Kaushik Narasimhan 2019-10-24 1 Questions and Objectives What is the effect of different levels of historical disturbance on bat species diversity, abundance, and community composition? What is the effect of different levels of historical disturbance on bat species diversity and abundance, community composition? H0: There is no difference in bat species diversity and abundance between forest types summary table - in progress Diversity – Using simpson Estimated richness – accumulation curves raw sp rich raw abundance mixed models on those Whittaker plots NMDS What is the effect of different forest types on vertical stratification of bats in the middle canopy? H0: Net height has no effect on the diversity and abundance of bats captured. - similar to 1) stratified by strata What environmental factors most account for differences in bat species diversity and abundance between forest types? Moon phase, temperature, conopy cover, cloud cover Mixed models e.g. raw richness ~ Moon phase + canopy cover + habitat type + Effort + 1|site H0: The is no difference in effect of environmental factors on bat species d and a Do bats captured in different forest types vary morphologically (don’t know if that is the right word to use. Maybe characters instead?) H0: Bats do not vary morphologically between forest types Response term : forearm length, ear, mass, condition (function mass vs. size) Checkout peig and green’s scaled mass index. Explanatory variables: Forest type Does bat diversity captured via detector differ from bat diversity captured via nets between forest types? H0: Diversity does not differ in forest types from different capture methods.

The QQ plot seems borderline, I will assume that this is non-parametric and use a kruskal-wallis test. ## ## Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test ## ## data: Feeding.Guild by Forest.Type ## Kruskal-Wallis chi-squared = 4.5387, df = 2, p-value = 0.1034 Not significant, p-value is .10 Ok, feeding guild itself is not significant, but what if we look at individual feeding guilds? High flying frugivores and low flying frugivores are both strongly represented. Lets test each one against forest type. First HFF: SLR seems like it is different… Lets test assumptions ## [1] 42.3 ## [1] 49.7 ## [1] 66 ## Levene's Test for Homogeneity of Variance (center = median) ## Df F value Pr(>F) ## group 2 0.0407 0.9603 ## 12 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1$HFF ## W = 0.8997, p-value = 0.09417 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "CCR", ]$HFF ## W = 0.8034, p-value = 0.08634 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "PCR", ]$HFF ## W = 0.75661, p-value = 0.03423 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: b1[b1$Forest.Type == "SLR", ]$HFF ## W = 0.92034, p-value = 0.5321 ## ## Shapiro-Wilk normality test ## ## data: aov.hff.resid ## W = 0.93866, p-value = 0.3658 Assumptions are met. ## Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) ## Forest.Type 2 179.7 89.87 1.706 0.223 ## Residuals 12 632.0 52.67 Not significant, p-value=0.223. 3 Chapter 2 3.1 Hypothesis 4: No difference in captures by height as a result of forest type

3 Chapter 2 3.1 Hypothesis 4: No difference in captures by height as a result of forest type My nets were subdivided into three sections: Low, Medium and High SLR captures are higher than other forest types in L and M nets, but high nets do not seem to have an impact. Lets test assumptions. ## [1] 25.8 ## [1] 16.3 ## [1] 138.7 ## [1] "Abun.l Levene test not significant, doesnt violate assumptions levene.Abun.l" ## [1] "Abun.l shapiro test is SIGNIFICANT, violates assumptions of normality, 0.0318420844659977" ## NULL ## [1] 16.7 ## [1] 16.8 ## [1] 44.8 ## [1] "Abun.m Levene test not significant, doesnt violate assumptions levene.Abun.m" ## [1] "Abun.m shapiro test not significant, doesnt violate assumptions" ## NULL ## [1] 19.3 ## [1] 21.2 ## [1] 4.5 ## [1] "Abun.h Levene test not significant, doesnt violate assumptions levene.Abun.h" ## [1] "Abun.h shapiro test not significant, doesnt violate assumptions" ## NULL Abundance for low violates assumption of normality and I will use KW test. Medium and high are good to go. ## ## Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test ## ## data: Abun.l by Forest.Type ## Kruskal-Wallis chi-squared = 3.3921, df = 2, p-value = 0.1834 ## Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) ## b1$Forest.Type 2 124.1 62.07 2.378 0.135 ## Residuals 12 313.2 26.10 ## Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) ## b1$Forest.Type 2 12.4 6.2 0.413 0.671 ## Residuals 12 180.0 15.0 Again and surprisingly, no significance here.
